frequently attacks the media, we consider both party ID and Trump approval to be potentially relevant moderators. We therefore plan to estimate results testing for subgroup differences between Trump approvers and disapprovers and between Republicans and Democrats in the appendix. We will test our experimental hypotheses on the outcome variables described above by analyzing the average treatment effect of assignment to treatment relative to the appropriate comparison condition. Where appropriate, we will compute and report appropriate auxiliary quantities from our models, including treatment effects by subgroup and differences in marginal effects between subgroups. (These may include subgroups defined by party or ideological self-identification, presidential job approval, political knowledge, etc. - see above). We measure political knowledge using an eight-item additive scale of statements where respondents can say "true", "false" or "don't know." Correct answers will be coded as 1; all others as 0. For any interaction terms, scales, and moderators, if results are consistent using a median/tercile split or indicators rather than a continuous scale, we may present the latter in the main text for ease of exposition and include the continuous scale results in an appendix. We will compute all marginal effects appropriate to test the hypotheses of interest from any interaction models described below. We will also use indicators to test whether the linearity assumption holds for interactions with continuous measures and replace those in the models below if it does not. (See Hainmueller et al N.d.) In some cases, we may present treatment effects estimated on different subsets of the data for expositional clarity. If so, we will verify that we can reject the null of no difference in treatment effects in a more complex interactive model reported in an appendix when possible. Don't know responses will be considered missing data for our outcome measures. If these are sufficiently common, we will consider coding them at the midpoint of the relevant scale. Missing covariates will be treated as missing. In our observational analyses, we will control for the following standard outcome measures: sex (indicator for female), age (indicators for age categories of 30-44, 45-59, and 60+; 18-29 excluded), race (indicator for nonwhite), education (college graduate with a bachelor's degree), and political knowledge (0-8 score). We will also compute and report summary statistics for our sample and may also report measures of respondent attention and comprehension, including response timing data and/or accuracy of answers to manipulation check questions about the stimulus articles. Our primary experimental effect estimates will be unweighted per Franco et al. (N.d.), though we may also report weighted results. All non-experimental (i.e., observational) analyses will use survey weights. The order of hypotheses and analyses in the final manuscript may be altered for expositional clarity. Where applicable, regression results for binary dependent variables will be verified for robustness using probit. Regression results for individual ordered dependent variables will be verified for robustness using ordered probit. Regression results for ordered scales constructed from multinomial data will be verified for robustness using multinomial logit or multinomial probit. Regression results for count variables will be verified for robustness using Poisson regression with robust standard errors or negative binomial regression.

registration_responses.q1: Media trust and news consumption: Evidence from survey and behavioral measures (second study)
registration_responses.q2: Andrew Guess | Brendan Nyhan | Jason Reifler
registration_responses.q5: We acknowledge funding/in-kind support from the Poynter Institute, Craig Newmark Philanthropies, and the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation program (grant agreement No 682758
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: This study seeks to understand how and why trust in the media is changing in the U.S. and how levels of media trust expressed in surveys correspond to actual information consumption behavior. To examine these questions, we previously conducted a two-wave public opinion survey on the YouGov Pulse panel that includes independent experimental randomizations in each wave. We are now conducting another one-wave public opinion survey with the YouGov/YouGov Pulse panels that includes an experimental randomization. In addition to collecting public opinion data during each of the two surveys, we are also passively collecting anonymized individual-level web traffic with users' consent, allowing us to measure their real-world behavior. Overall, our hypotheses and analysis will consist of two primary components: -An observational analysis of descriptive patterns of media trust and information consumption in our survey and behavioral data. -Tests of the effect of our experimental treatments on attitudes toward the media (survey outcomes) and information consumption (behavioral outcomes). Note: This is a modified version of the preregistration for our first study (20171122AC).
registration_responses.q16: Survey evidence of differences in media attitudes To test our hypotheses about news media attitudes, it is first necessary to determine how to best measure them. The following post-treatment survey questions will serve as our dependent variables. Using the thematic groupings below, we will examine whether these questions scale together or not using only data from the control condition (which is not affected by the experimental manipulation). Trust/confidence in media (general and specific organizations): -Confidence in people running the press -Trust in CNN (post-treatment measure only) -Confidence and trust in mass media, network television news, local television news in your community, online-only news outlets, national newspapers, and local newspapers in your community Press accuracy/bias: -Accuracy of news posted online -Major news organizations fabricate -Does the media deal fairly with all sides or favor one side? Support for press freedom: -Criticism of leaders prevents politicians from doing their job (versus keeps them from doing things that shouldn't be done) -Revoke broadcast licenses RQ1: Do measures of media trust and confidence in the press, perceived accuracy or bias, and support for limitations on freedom of the press correspond closely with each other? Based on the results of this analysis, we will construct a composite measures of media attitudes that we will use in the analyses below in addition to specific measures of media trust, perceptions of accuracy/bias, and support for press freedom. The hypotheses of interest below will typically be described as examining "attitudes toward the media" or similar terms, which refers to the composite outcome measure we intend to construct as a result of this analysis. We will also separately estimate effects on the three subscales listed above of media trust, perceptions of press accuracy/bias, and support for press freedom specifically for each hypothesis. Further details about how these measures will be constructed will be provided in the statistical analysis section below. Attitudes toward the news media vary widely. Over the last several decades, leading Republican and conservative voices have accused the mainstream media of having a liberal bias. The flow of negative claims about the press have escalated since 2016. Donald Trump has repeatedly attacked the press as "fake news" and accused it of fabrications on the campaign trail and now in the White House. We therefore expect that Republicans, conservatives, and Trump approvers will, on average, express significantly more negative attitudes toward the media than Democrats, liberals, and Trump disapprovers, respectively: H1a: Republicans will have more negative attitudes toward the news media than Democrats. Similarly, conservatives will have more negative attitudes toward the news media than either liberals or moderates and Trump approvers will have more negative attitudes toward the news media than Trump disapprovers. We also expect that differences in perceptions of media bias and and trust between Republicans and Democrats, liberals and conservatives, and Trump approvers and Trump disapprovers will vary by respondents' levels of political knowledge: H1b: The gap between Republicans and Democrats in attitudes toward the media will be greater among respondents with higher political knowledge than those with less knowledge. Similarly, the gap between liberals and conservatives and between Trump approvers and disapprovers will be greater among respondents with higher political knowledge than those with less knowledge. (We will also conduct a descriptive analysis of how attitudes toward the media vary over time between our two surveys and when comparing our survey measures of these attitudes to those in other surveys that have used identical question wording. Given that our media attitude measures are measured post-treatment, we will verify that these findings hold using only respondents in our control condition.) Survey data/behavioral data We will conduct descriptive analyses of the extent that self-reports of news consumption relate to actual news consumption and the relationship between media trust and news consumption: RQ2a: To what extent are self-reports of outlet-specific news consumption correlated with actual consumption of news from those outlets? RQ2b: To what extent are attitudes toward the news media correlated with mainstream news consumption? RQ2c: To what extent is outlet-specific trust correlated with consumption of news from those outlets? Experimental effects on beliefs and attitudes measured in surveys We also embed an experiment in our survey that uses random assignment to test whether and how the press reports a story affects attitudes toward the media and views of public figures involved in a controversy. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four treatment conditions. Specifically, the experiment we have designed examines the controversy over whether Rep. Jim Jordan (R-OH) knew about sexual abuse of athletes at Ohio State University when we has a wrestling coach there. We experimentally vary whether sources in the article are named or anonymous to see if this affects beliefs and attitudes about the media or Jordan (i.e., do people believe Jordan’s accusers less and/or trust the media less if they are anonymous?). In addition, we contrast a conventionally balanced “he said,” “she said” story with a version in which a potentially false or misleading claim is placed between accurate information. We will again test whether this approach affects beliefs and attitudes toward Jordan and/or the media. We expect to observe heterogeneous effects in response to negative information about a prominent Republican. Relative to the balanced condition with a named source, anonymous or non-balanced coverage of Jordan should have a greater negative effect on attitudes and beliefs about Jordan among Trump disapprovers and Democrats (for whom it is more likely to be attitude-consistent) than among Trump approvers and Republicans, respectively. We conversely expect attitudes toward the media to become more negative among Trump approvers and Republicans when anonymous sources are used or coverage is not balanced than among Trump disapprovers and Democrats. Our hypotheses and research questions about the experiment are the following: H2a: Compared to the control condition, exposure to the named source/balanced condition will reduce the warmth of feelings toward Jordan and increase beliefs that he knew about alleged abuse. H2b: Compared to the named source/balanced condition, the anonymous condition will worsen attitudes toward CNN and the press (including worsening beliefs that the media fabricates information and does not deal fairly with all sides). It will also will have a less negative effect on feelings toward Jordan and beliefs that he knew about alleged abuse than the named source/balanced condition. H2c: Compared to the named source/balanced condition, the non-balanced condition will create more negative feelings toward Jordan and increase beliefs that he knew about alleged abuse. RQ3: Compared to the named source/balanced condition, does the non-balanced condition worsen attitudes toward CNN and the press (including worsening beliefs that the media fabricates information and does not deal fairly with all sides)? (Note: We predict heterogeneous treatment effects on attitudes towards CNN and the press in H3a and H3b and thus pose a research question here for the main effect of the non-balanced condition due to the potential for offsetting treatment effects by party ID or Trump approval.) H3a: Compared to the named source/balanced condition, anonymous and non-balanced conditions will both worsen attitudes toward CNN and the press (including worsening beliefs that the media fabricates information and does not deal fairly with all sides) among Trump approvers and Republicans. H3b: Compared to the named source/balanced condition, anonymous and non-balanced conditions will worsen attitudes toward CNN and the press (including worsening beliefs that the media fabricates information and does not deal fairly with all sides) more among Trump approvers than disapprovers and more among Republicans than Democrats. H3c: Compared to the named source/balanced condition, the effect of the anonymous and non-balanced conditions on feelings toward Jordan and beliefs that he knew about alleged abuse will be lower for Trump approvers compared to disapprovers and for Republicans compared to Democrats.
registration_responses.q17: As discussed above, our hypotheses are tested using data collected from a public opinion survey with an embedded experiment in which we also collect the web traffic data on a person's computer for respondents who are members of the YouGov Pulse panel (Pulse panelists are only a portion of the full sample). We will examine our research questions and hypotheses using responses to survey questions and online behavioral data (where available). The outcome measures will be coded as specified below. We will then conduct the statistical analyses described below. Randomization approach Respondents will be randomized by YouGov with equal probability into one of four conditions: a control condition in which they view an unrelated message or to one of three versions of an article about the controversy over whether Rep. Jim Jordan (R-OH) knew about sexual abuse of athletes at Ohio State University when he has a wrestling coach there. We specifically compare a conventionally balanced story in which the key source in the article is named with ones in which either the key source is anonymous or in which the article is structured so that a potentially false or misleading claim is placed between accurate information rather than being balanced. Respondents, data collection and blinding We are conducting this study using a YouGov/YouGov Pulse panel of US residents age 18 or older, which is recruited and maintained by YouGov. We expect this sample, which will be collected on the YouGov platform, to consist of approximately 2000 participants, including approximately 700 from YouGov Pulse. Respondents are blind to condition. The data, which are anonymized, will include survey data and online behavioral data from respondents willing to install tracking software who are part of the YouGov Pulse panel. The online tracking panel is currently branded as YouGov Pulse. Panelists are recruited from YouGov's traditional participant pool via incentives. The data to be used for this study covers multiple weeks of web traffic, with data collected both prior to the survey and after the survey. The software tracks web traffic (minus form entries, passwords, and financial transactions) for all browsers installed on a user's computer and can be uninstalled at any time. Users provide full consent to download and install the software and identifying information is not collected. Interventions and dates of administration Invitations to participate in the study began to be sent on July 26, 2018. Data collection by YouGov will continue until the number of respondents meets the target sample size. Termination of data collection will be determined by YouGov, not the researchers, and will be blind to outcomes. The researchers will remain blind to the data until data collection is complete and this preregistration is filed. Eligibility and exclusion criteria for participants All U.S. residents age 18 or older are eligible to participate. Participants must be members of the YouGov or YouGov Pulse panels to be selected for inclusion. Primary and secondary outcome measures We describe the coding of survey and behavioral outcome measures below. In some cases, we will combine multiple measures to construct composite outcome measures. In those cases, we will use the procedures described in the statistical analysis section of this preregistration. Coding of raw outcome measures: [Pre-treatment] Please indicate which news sources below that you have heard of, regardless of whether you use them or not. If you are unsure, please DO NOT click it. (randomize order)  -Fox News -The New York Times -CNN  Of the news sources you have heard of, please indicate how much trust and confidence you have in each one when it comes to reporting the news fully, accurately and fairly? (grid with sources indicated as known above; randomize order)  -Great deal of trust [4] -Fair amount of trust [3] -Not very much trust [2] -No trust at all [1] We would like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and institutions who are in the news these days using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person or institution. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel favorable toward the person or institution and that you don't care too much for that person or institution. You would rate them at the 50 degree mark if you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward them. If we come to a person or institution whose name you don't recognize, you don't need to rate them. Others think that such criticism is worth it because it keeps political leaders from doing things that should not be done. Which position is closer to your opinion? -Keep political leaders from doing their job [0] -Keep political leaders from doing things that shouldn't be done [1] In presenting the news dealing with political and social issues, do you think that news organizations deal fairly with all sides, or do they tend to favor one side? -Deal fairly with all sides [1] -Tend to favor one side [0] Based on what you know, how often do you believe the nation's major news organizations fabricate news stories? -Never [5] -Once in a while [4] -About half the time [3] -Most of the time [2] -All the time [1] Do you agree or disagree that the federal government should have the power to revoke broadcast licenses of major news organizations it says are fabricating news stories?  -Agree strongly [1] -Agree somewhat  [2] -Neither agree nor disagree [3] -Disagree somewhat [4] -Disagree strongly [5] We would like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and institutions who are in the news these days using something we call the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don’t feel favorable toward the person or institution and that you don’t care too much for that person or institution. You would rate them at the 50 degree mark if you don’t feel particularly warm or cold toward them. If we come to a person or institution whose name you don’t recognize, you don’t need to rate them. (randomize order) -Rep. Jim Jordan (R-OH) [0-100] Please indicate how much trust and confidence you have in each news source listed below when it comes to reporting the news fully, accurately and fairly. If you are not familiar with the source, please select don't know. -The New York Times -The Economist -The Guardian -Fox News -CNN Response options: -Great deal of trust [4] -Fair amount of trust [3] -Not very much trust [2] -No trust at all [1] -Don't know [treated as missing data] Recently, there have been news stories about accusations that Jim Jordan, a Republican member of Congress, knew of sexual misconduct by an Ohio State University doctor. Which of the following statements best describes your view of Jordan’s actions in this matter? -Jordan definitely knew about the misconduct [1] -Jordan probably knew about the conduct [2] -Unclear / I don’t know / I haven’t heard [3] -Jordan probably did not know about the misconduct [4] -Jordan definitely did not know about the misconduct [5] Note: For consistency, all dependent variables are coded such that higher values indicate more positive attitudes toward the media. However, we may reverse the direction of coding for expositional reasons when it is more intuitive for higher values to indicate more negative perceptions (e.g., greater perceptions of bias). Similarly, Jordan-related dependent variables are coded such that higher values indicate more positive views of him. We will assess the dimensionality of the variables measuring attitudes toward the media using factor analysis with these variables. We will first estimate a composite measure of media attitudes using the loadings from the first dimension of a factor analysis estimated on the control group. We will then use those loadings to calculate the composite media attitude score for all respondents. As discussed above, the composite measure includes questions that tap subtle but important differences in dimensions of attitudes towards the media and the press (attitudes about trust/confidence in media, perceptions of press accuracy/bias, and support for press freedom). We will therefore also estimate separate factor scores for each subscale (trust/confidence in media, perceptions of press accuracy/bias, and support for press freedom) using an identical procedure to the main composite measure. (All factor analysis will be estimated using principal-components factor analysis with a varimax rotation.) (We will confirm that the results are similar in MPLUS using the ESEM WLSVM estimator to verify that findings are consistent between data treated as continuous and data treated as categorical.) Behavioral outcome measure coding: We will measure visits to the websites of the outlets listed in the question "Which of these websites have you visited or used in the past week for news, if any?" and in "Please indicate how much trust and confidence you have in each news source listed below when it comes to reporting the news fully, accurately and fairly." We will specify this time period in the statistical analysis section below. We will code news and information websites as "mainstream" if any of the following is true: -they are on the list of websites visited for news in our media exposure survey question (see above; based on behavioral data from a previous YouGov Pulse study) and are not affiliated with a particular political party or ideology; -had at least 5 million total unique monthly visits in our 2015 comScore data and ideology slant scores (Bakshy et al. 2015) between -0.55 and 0.55 inclusive and are based in the U.S.; -it is a Wikipedia article; -it is associated with one of the broadcast news networks (ABC, CBS, or NBC); -it is WSJ.com (omitted from our survey question because it is paywalled, but people may choose WSJ articles from a Google search) -it is one of the major fact-checking national organizations (PolitiFact, Snopes, or Factcheck.org; the Washington Post Fact Checker is excluded because it is part of the Washington Post, which is already a qualifying media outlet under the criteria above) The list is: abcnews.go.com, aol.com, buzzfeed.com, cbsnews.com, chicagotribune.com, cnbc.com, cnn.com, examiner.com, factcheck.org, fivethirtyeight.com, latimes.com, msn.com, nbcnews.com, nydailynews.com, nypost.com, nytimes.com, politico.com, politifact.com, realclearpolitics.com, snopes.com, theatlantic.com, thedailybeast.com, time.com, usnews.com, washingtonpost.com, wikipedia.org, wsj.com We count news and information websites as "non-mainstream" if they are not on the mainstream list above and either of the following is true: -they are on the list of websites visited for news in our media exposure survey question (which was based on traffic from a previous YouGov Pulse study); -they are classified as focusing on "hard news" topics by Bakshy et al. (2015) but fall outside the [-0.55, 0.55] ideological range (out of -2 to 2) The set of qualifying websites in this set includes Breitbart, Daily Kos, Fox News, Huffington Post, Talking Points Memo, and The Blaze. We will consider effects on total webpages visited from mainstream and non-mainstream news and information sources using the criteria described above (we expect that most people will visit at least one website in both categories during the study period and thus exclude a binary measure). Duplicate visits to webpages will not be counted if they are successive (i.e., a page that was reloaded after first opening it). URLs are cleaned of referrer information and other parameters before de-duplication. Statistical analyses All models will be estimated using ordinary least squares with robust standard errors. We will estimate all experimental models in the paper using the control condition as a baseline and present those in the main text or the appendix, but to facilitate reader understanding of difference between the named source/balanced condition and the other two treatment conditions we may report models using the named source/balanced conditio as the baseline and excluding the control condition (results will be identical). We will compute the appropriate linear combinations of coefficients to test the relevant hypotheses when appropriate. frequently attacks the media, we consider both party ID and Trump approval to be potentially relevant moderators. We therefore plan to estimate results testing for subgroup differences between Trump approvers and disapprovers and between Republicans and Democrats in the appendix. We will test our experimental hypotheses on the outcome variables described above by analyzing the average treatment effect of assignment to treatment relative to the appropriate comparison condition. Where appropriate, we will compute and report appropriate auxiliary quantities from our models, including treatment effects by subgroup and differences in marginal effects between subgroups. (These may include subgroups defined by party or ideological self-identification, presidential job approval, political knowledge, etc. - see above). We measure political knowledge using an eight-item additive scale of statements where respondents can say "true", "false" or "don't know." Correct answers will be coded as 1; all others as 0. For any interaction terms, scales, and moderators, if results are consistent using a median/tercile split or indicators rather than a continuous scale, we may present the latter in the main text for ease of exposition and include the continuous scale results in an appendix. We will compute all marginal effects appropriate to test the hypotheses of interest from any interaction models described below. We will also use indicators to test whether the linearity assumption holds for interactions with continuous measures and replace those in the models below if it does not. (See Hainmueller et al N.d.) In some cases, we may present treatment effects estimated on different subsets of the data for expositional clarity. If so, we will verify that we can reject the null of no difference in treatment effects in a more complex interactive model reported in an appendix when possible. Don't know responses will be considered missing data for our outcome measures. If these are sufficiently common, we will consider coding them at the midpoint of the relevant scale. Missing covariates will be treated as missing. In our observational analyses, we will control for the following standard outcome measures: sex (indicator for female), age (indicators for age categories of 30-44, 45-59, and 60+; 18-29 excluded), race (indicator for nonwhite), education (college graduate with a bachelor's degree), and political knowledge (0-8 score). We will also compute and report summary statistics for our sample and may also report measures of respondent attention and comprehension, including response timing data and/or accuracy of answers to manipulation check questions about the stimulus articles. Our primary experimental effect estimates will be unweighted per Franco et al. (N.d.), though we may also report weighted results. All non-experimental (i.e., observational) analyses will use survey weights. The order of hypotheses and analyses in the final manuscript may be altered for expositional clarity. Where applicable, regression results for binary dependent variables will be verified for robustness using probit. Regression results for individual ordered dependent variables will be verified for robustness using ordered probit. Regression results for ordered scales constructed from multinomial data will be verified for robustness using multinomial logit or multinomial probit. Regression results for count variables will be verified for robustness using Poisson regression with robust standard errors or negative binomial regression.
